content:
Until Thunderbird knows the proper sender and receiver server names, and you tell it your user name and password, you won't be able to send or receive email. Out of the box, Thunderbird will try to use a new feature called "Account hub", which keeps a database of email services, and supplies the server information, if known, from that database. I have had good luck with this feature, but I have heard that some people have had trouble with it. Sounds like you're one of them. So, go to Tools |Settings | General | Account Hub and turn of the option "Create accounts in the new Account Hub" for now.

Before you proceed, you need to do some research and arm yourself with the proper settings for your email service, plus your user name and password. The settings should, hopefully, be on their web site somewhere. I tried looking up "websitename.com" and "sunset-daily.com" but I nothing came up. The information you will need is:

- Incoming email server name (choose IMAP unless you have a reason not to) - Incoming email server port (probably 993) - Incoming Connection security (probably SSL/TLS or STARTTLS) - Incoming Authentication method (probably Normal or plain password)

- Outgoing (SMTP) email server name - Outgoing email server port (probably 465) - Outgoing server connection security (probably SSL/TLS) - Outgoing server authentication method (probably Normal password)

Once you have all that information in front of you, choose Tools | Account settings | Add new account and follow the prompts.
creator: rednoise

content: I am a novice with Linux, so I'll offer suggestions that use the file manager. - locate the profile on olddisk. POP messages will be in the Mail\<POPaccount> folder. look for files such as input, sent, trash. Ignore the msf files. the addressbook will be in the root folder of the profile. look for two files: abook.sqlite and history.sqlite - be sure that thunderbird is not running - copy the above mentioned files and paste the addressbook files into the profile's root folder, overwriting the initial ones there, and place the message files into the Mail\Local Folders folder. That will allow you to view messages although they will be separate from their respective accounts. - restart thunderbird and all should be there

content:
Samuel Shehata said
Hi Tirate, Thank you for your email. I even have an issue adding my personal Outlook. I have created what is so called "app password" on Outlook and I did click done on Outlook, copied and paste it to Thunderbird, but not going through.

Disable the account hub in Settings/General, then add the account from ⇶ - New Account - Email. The correct settings should be detected automatically, which include OAuth2 authentication. Make sure cookies are accepted in TB (not browser) Settings, and when the OAuth window appears, enter the account (not app) password to grant TB access.

content:
The addon added an extra support feature to Thunderbird. The instructions on using the addon are at 

https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/outlook-address-book-enabler/   From the addresbook pane, you will find the ability add an LDAP server by clicking the icon to the left of the NEW CONTACT icon and then follow instructions as in the URL i included. I cannot speak to Outlook group ids. All I can suggest is to review content of exported csv or ldif files you created from Outlook. If you prefer to import a csv or ldif file, it can be complex as the fields don't readily line up. To be successful in this here is my suggestion:
  1. create at least one email address in the thunderbird address book
  2. then, highlight the addressbook and click the three dots to the right of the addressbook name and export the file
  3. you mow have a template
  4. open the file in a spreadsheet program to view the top row. this tells you the layout of the thunderbird addressbook
  5. now, open the exported file from Outlook in the spreadsheet program and adjust the columns to match the thunderbird layout
  6. now, click tools>import>import from a file and follow the menus for addressbooks

content:
There shouldn't be any issues with a consumer hotmail account, i.e. standard IMAP. I suggest you click Manual config. and enter these settings:

outlook.office365.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

smtp.office365.com, 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2, email address

Don't enter the account password - that will be needed in the OAuth authentication window on first connection to the server.

Another way to avoid interference is to add the account Offline (click icon at left end of status bar). Once added, go back online, select Inbox, enter account password in OAuth window.

content:
Is the old computer still available? I hope so. The built-in export tool causes numerous problems. The following steps WORK.

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

Question: were the lost messages in an IMAP or POP account?

content:
I have no idea if the login page you are getting is related to mail, contact or calendars.do you? I think not or you would not be talking about "the google login screen from Hell!"

When you set up an account in thunderbird with gmail or Google if you want to call it that you by necesity have to use oauth authentication to connect to the google mail servers to get mail, contact and calendars.

You are calling the request to authenticate so the mail client can do it's job "the google login screen from Hell!"

So to answer you questions. 1. Login to google using the screen and authenticate Thunderbird to do it's job with regard to the gmail and what did you call them "Google Domains" 2. No as you are not logged into your account the system is waitin g for you to authorize it to manage mail. It is not blocking it is waiting on you to complete the setup and authentication process. 3. Forget it unless you actually authenticate it will never work.

What you are essentially doing is poking your debit card into the automatic teller machine and refusing to enter the pin when requested and then seeking support from the bank because your card does not work.

content:
I am a novice at Linux, but I will share what little that may help. When you copy the Thunderbird folder, one of the primary reasons is that the Thunderbird folder contains a file named profiles.ini. That is a simple text file that tells Thunderbird where the profile is located. If thunderbird starts and sends message that profile not found, it is because that file is either not found, or does not point to the active profile. I suggest looking at a default setup on Linux to see exactly where the components are - the Thunderbird folder, the profiles.ini file, and the profile.

Be sure you're copying the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder and NOT the appdata\local\thunderbird one.
